ratings.comment: The class started very slowly, and was pretty boring, however about 1/3 of the way through it became much more intersting. He's a very nice guy, and is willing to help you on pretty much whatever. The tests are difficult, study supply shocks for the second midterm and the final.
Knows the material well, but does not do a good job of presenting it. Lecture is taught right out of the textbook.

He's a lot more helpful in person or via email than he is in lecture. He is a really smart guy but he doesn't utilize it; all he does is use the slides/homework that Pearson provides. Exams weren't easy at all, but he gave us a full page cheat sheet where we could write whatever for the exams (front side only for midterms, both sides for final)

He's not a good lecturer. Unprepared, too quiet, has difficulty articulating thoughts; reading the book was far more helpful, which his lectures followed. Homework was online and taking those very seriously was the key to success. Exam questions were sometimes worded awkwardly, which was often more confusing than the material itself.

Learned from the textbook.  If you go to lecture you cannot hear him anyways so I didnt attend at all. He is a smart guy, so I bet if you go to office hours he would be interesting to talk with.  Wish I had someone else because I actually enjoy the material.
He hit rock bottom. The absolute worst prof I have had.

Worst professor I have ever had in my 3 years at UW-Madison. I stopped attending lecture after the second week and just took notes from the book. It was much clearer than he is and I did pretty well in the class. Bianchi seems very smart, but he cannot teach and just mumbles and reads from his slides. Avoid at all costs.

He talks pretty quiet, and can be confusing at times. But he is helpful, and if you go to lecture, he hints at what is on exams. IS-LM models make up a huge part of the class, which is a very hard topic. He explains it far better in office hours. Gives a very nice curve.
The worst professor i have had in my 2 years so far. Horrible lecturer, very unclear on what to know. Gets lost in his own lectures all the time. Overall, AVOID AT ALL COSTS!

The class size of Econ 302 of this semester is around 150, after one week the semester started, there is only around people keep attending the lecture. he voice is very low and confused. He also make the second Midterm very very hard. So if you dont have to take 302 immediately, DO NOT choose his Class.

He is the worst professor I've had. I stopped attending lecture as he reads straight off of the slides provided by Pearson, and the book is clearer than he is. The first exam was fairly easy. The second exam consisted of 70% short answer on one specific topic he never explained well, nor did the book. The class average dropped significantly.

The lectures were really boring right away, but after the first midterm they got much much better. The content was pretty dry right away so that may have been the cause of it. The exams have short answer questions based on lecture, which not many people attended so the curve was very generous. Go to lecture. MC questions on exams are like homework.

Lecture is unclear and boring. He just use materials supplied by Pearson and it seems like he does not prepare for the lectures. The material covered in this class is not difficult, but his lecture makes it difficult to understand. It's better to read the text than to attend the lecture.

Horrible professor. Lectures are unclear and straight from Pearson's lecture slides (not his own), homework is also through Pearson. He makes it impossible to know what to study for his exams, as he doesn't write his own slides or homework, or even correct any homework. I really wanted to learn more about macro, but with him I learned nothing.

Kind of boring and unclear sometimes, but he's willing to help you out with any problems. Easy online homework and lectures basically follow the book to the letter, but would still recommend attending them and the discussions for sure. Hardly read the book and just used lecture notes/discussion materials to study and did well.
